div.head: To the Courteous Reader.
div.p: PRovidence having di≈øpo≈øed of me from fifteen years of age, to this day, in the way of Phy≈øick. Be≈øides my particular In≈øtructions from others; I can ≈øafely ≈øay, I have laboured night and day, and that for ≈øome years together to Attain to the right ∆≤nder≈øtanding thereof; that ≈øo according as the Will of God might be, I might do nothing therein; but that which might be ≈øerviceable, by Gods ble≈ø≈øing to my Neighbours, and a good Con≈øcience to my ≈øelf, and could if need were, give ≈øuch an account thereof, as I doubt not but would be ≈øatisfactory to all, and every Enbia≈øed Per≈øon or Per≈øons; but what hath allready been done by me, (and that in a Publick way) in that perticular may ≈øuffice, always remembring: Arbor ex fructibus cogno≈øcitur.

Some there are, who≈øe Intere≈øts Tran≈øports them beyond their Rea≈øon; That would like cunning men, ca≈øt a mi≈øt before the Eyes of others, and darkning my Reputation by fal≈øe Reports and evil Surmi≈øings, which I wonder not much at, becau≈øe, Impies voluptas e≈øt alienam famam laedere, The≈øe I pitty, and Attribute it more to the want of charity, then ≈øound knowledge, there own or there friends Intere≈øt, then ≈øafe and ≈øober Intelligence; whil≈øt I as the Fox: The more I am Cur≈øed by envious Men; the better I ≈øpeed, through the ble≈ø≈øing of a good God,

Let the World and them know, that I have an Antidote through Gods Grace, that will keep and pre≈øerve me amid≈øt all their Poy≈øonous Arrows; and that I have ≈øo much the ≈øpirit of a Man, that I lightly value their Evil, either of thoughts, words or actions; And have ≈øo much the ≈øpirit of a Chri≈øtian, that I heartily wi≈øh their good and welfare; and this not only in point of Prudence, but al≈øo in point of Duty; knowing, that Laborandum e≈øt ut pro≈øimus: and not only ≈øo, but to love our Enemies.

What great Ob≈øtructions or Stumbling-blocks I found in my Minor Studies, po≈ø≈øibly for want of profound learning; the way then being more locked up then now it is: and partly becau≈øe our Authors are ≈øo Voliminous. I ≈øhall not here relate, ≈øave only that through Gods a≈ø≈øi≈øtance; great pains, and helps of tho≈øe that had traced the way before me, at la≈øt the way was made plain and ea≈øie, and every
Material Ob≈øtruction bowed before me, and hoy≈øting ≈øayl immediately came to the Haven of my Expectation.

Where taking great delight in thinking of what was pa≈øt, at la≈øt began to think of what was yet to come, and ≈øo remembring that Nemo ≈øibi Na≈øcitur, I began, and I hope in the fear of God, to put my knowledg into practi≈øe, having a fair opportunity thereunto, which I thought would be my prudence not to neglect, for occa≈øio non Negligenda, be it either for the good of our ≈øelves or others. Therefore at all times, and ≈øeveral ways, I have endeavoured, according to my weak Capacity to be ≈øervicable in my Generation, and having lately been under a ≈øevere Providence, in being di≈øinhabited by the late dreadful fire at London, was in little time acquainted in this place, and as ≈øeveral places in re≈øpect to their Scituation, Con≈øtitution of Ground and Water; with the Diet, Excerci≈øe and manners of the People, are ≈øubject to ≈øome perticular Di≈øea≈øe; So this place for ≈øeveral rea≈øons ea≈øily to be given, be≈øides its being ≈øubject to all Di≈øea≈øes in common with others: it hath two Di≈øea≈øes that are more Epidemical Viz. The Scurvey for one, but the Ague in ≈øpecial: The former, Viz, The Scurvey, it is a Spleenetical Di≈øtemper, ari≈øing from a peculiar degree of Malignity through the putrifaction of Melancholly humours: and is known by variety of Symptomes, Viz. Redne≈øs, Itching and Putrefaction of the Mouth and Gums: Spots in the Leggs, which are fir≈øt Red, afterward Purple, Blew and Black; Straightne≈øs or Shortne≈øs of Breath, Lazine≈øs and Heavine≈øs of the whole Body, Weak and anequal Pul≈øe: ∆≤rine for the mo≈øt part Red and clear like Lye: Pains in the Hips, Knees, Joints, and ≈øeveral parts, all most like, tho≈øe that have defiled them≈øelves with the French Di≈øea≈øe, ≈øave only this Difference: the pain of the Pox, is between the Joints, and if it continue long, maketh Knots, and there are or have been other Symptomes thereof, as Running of the Reines, ∆≤lcor of the Yard, Bubo, and the like; but the Scurvey pains ≈øeize upon all parts Indifferently, and other ≈øignes of Melancholly, or a very ≈øharp and ≈øalt Diet do averre, there is often Head-Ach and Tooth-Ach al≈øo in the Scurvey: Somtimes Pal≈øies and Convul≈øions, as al≈øo a loo≈øe Belly, ≈øtrong Breath, a Con≈øumation of the Body, and an Intermiting Feavour or Ague; The latter of which being the more ≈øpecial trouble≈øome and common Di≈øea≈øe: Here I have thought good to treat only of it at this time; and as I have one purpo≈øe done this to do good; ≈øo I will endeavour to do it to the purpo≈øe that it may do good, as to the Di≈øcription and Curation; and may ≈øerve for all ≈øorts of Agues in Men Women or Children. O Read with under≈øtanding, Judge with Charity, and practi≈øe upon your ≈øelves or others with prayer and ≈øupplication: and I doubt not but you will reap much advantage and profit which is the harty de≈øire of thy Friend and Servant.

div.head: The De≈øcription and Cure of the Kenti≈øh, and all other Agues.
div.p: AGues are of two ≈øorts; Cureable or Uncurable. The Curable are tho≈øe that come in a common way of Providence: and all Per≈øons and Degrees of Men are equally lyable to the ≈øame; and are commonly thus di≈øtingui≈øhed; A Quotidian, or every day Ague: A Tertian, or every other day Ague: A Quartan, or every third day Ague: Computing the time or di≈øtance of the Fitts right, will ≈øupply that ≈øeeming defect that is in the Terms.

Every of which Agues have therefore divi≈øions; as Ligitimate, or Illigitimate, Simple, Double, or Triple; which cau≈øeth ≈øome more then ordinary difficulty, rightly to di≈øcern between a ≈øimple Quotidian; a double Tertian; and a triple Quartan; each coming every day, and that very near alike: But the diligent Ob≈øerver of Time, and ≈øome particular Symptoms may notwith≈øtanding ea≈øily gue≈øs.

The Uncurable I reckon are tho≈øe that are not ≈øent in a common way of Providence, but more immediately from God in the way of ≈øpecial Judgement; ≈øuch as I≈ørael of old were threatned withal, Levit. 26.16. and they admit of no Phy≈øical Cure, Deut. 28.22. but are like the ungodly King Jehorams Di≈øea≈øe of his Bowels, which will certainly de≈øtroy: Notwith≈øtanding the wi≈øe≈øt of men be concerned, and the very be≈øt of means be u≈øed, 2 Chron. 21.18, 19. Some ≈øuch Agues I have ≈øeen in my time, which ≈øurely are no other then the fruit of ≈øin, which becau≈øe it di≈øplea≈øed God, and brings Evil upon our ≈øelves: Let us take the P≈øalmi≈øts advice, and ≈øtand in awe and ≈øin not; P≈øal. 4.4. But it is the former ≈øort of Agues, viz. Tho≈øe that are Cureable by Phy≈øical Admini≈øtrations that I concern my ≈øelf herewith, for what≈øoever others may think or believe, I am of that faith, that all di≈øea≈øes (coming not as afore≈øaid) are cureable. Only ob≈øerve, as formerly I have hinted el≈øewhere, That although I do believe that all Di≈øea≈øes what≈øoever are Cureable,, yet they are not Curable in all Per≈øons. My bu≈øine≈øs herein is to do two things; Fir≈øt to di≈øcover to you what an Ague is: And, Secondly, To di≈øcover how it is to be Cured: In both I will be plain and brief, and (yet I hope home, and full) to your content and ≈øatisfaction.

Fir≈øt, we ≈øhall enquire what an Ague is; Many are the Opinions of all ≈øorts of Per≈øons concerning Agues: Some think it a ≈øtrange thing, but they know not what: The more ignorant, and evil Spirit; but coming they know not whence.

Phy≈øicians them≈øelves differ in their Judgments concerning this Di≈øea≈øe, as well as in the way of Cure; my Task is ≈øo much the harder; however we ≈øhall declare our Apprehen≈øions, and leave it with ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to better Judgments, and believing that there are ≈øome that are able to ≈øay more; other ≈øome as much, and other ≈øome not ≈øo much; to the latter of which as I intend this mo≈øt chiefly: ≈øo it will find mo≈øt welcome.

But our an≈øwer to the above enquiry is; that an Ague is no other then an Intermiting Feavour, and every Intermiting Feavour is commonly and properly called an Ague, which doth ari≈øe from putrefaction of rotten humors.

And its to be ob≈øerved that tho≈øe putrifying humours do rot either within the Ve≈ø≈øels, or el≈øe without the Ve≈ø≈øels, when they rot within the Ve≈ø≈øels, either all the humours do putrifie and rot equally, and cau≈øe Synochus Putrida.

Or el≈øe our only humour putrifieth and ≈øo cau≈øeth a common and ordinary continual Feaver, and according as the humour is that putrifieth, ≈øo is the Feaver either a continual Quotidian or a continual Tertian, or a continual Quartan. But tho≈øe homours rot al≈øo without the Ve≈ø≈øels, and as from the putrefaction within Springs continual: ≈øo from the putrifaction without, comes intermiting Feavours, or Agues: coming upon the per≈øon ≈øooner or later, according as the humour is that putrifieth. For the Spirits ri≈øeth up at certain times & oppo≈øeth that rottenne≈øs with heat, as an Enemy to Nature, and at the end of the combat returns home and according as the enemy remains either in ≈øtrength or vigor, ≈øo more or le≈øs good or evil Symptomes follow: And if the putrifying humor be flegm, then the Spirits return to oppo≈øe it the very next day, hence the Quotidian, or every day Ague.
And if the putrifying humor be Choller, then the Spirits return ≈øtill to oppo≈øe it every other day; hence the Tertian or every other day Ague.
And if the putrifying humor be Melancholly, then the Spirits return to oppo≈øe it every third day, hence the Quartan or every third day Ague.

The cau≈øe of the inequallity, that is to ≈øay: why one returns ≈øooner then another, why one comes every day; another every other day; and another every third day is, Becau≈øe the Flegmatick humor recollects it ≈øelf ≈øooner, and ≈øo makes new work for the Spirits, and ≈øo its returns are accordingly. Choller which is accounted hot of it ≈øelf in re≈øpects of the Spirits oppo≈øing it with heat, doth occa≈øion a very hot combat and doth not ≈øo ≈øoon recollect it ≈øelf as the former: and therefore is oppo≈øed but every other day.

Melancholly is a Dregy humor, and doth not recollect or recruit it ≈øelf as ≈øoon as the others do, but becau≈øe it is ≈øoft and vi≈øcous (the ≈øeat of which al≈øo
being more remote) it is not ≈øo ea≈øie to overcome; notwith≈øtanding it is oppo≈øed every third day: And all the≈øe are changed one into another, or one joined with another, according as one while one putrifying humor, another while another is to be oppo≈øed.

This is the mo≈øt common and general opinion concerning Agues: which I mu≈øt Imbrace and not condemn, there being much of Rea≈øon and truth in it rightly under≈øtood; and al≈øo becau≈øe it ≈øtandeth upon the ≈øhoulders of famous and learned men: which is ≈øufficient Authority for ≈øuch a beleif.

Neverthele≈øs I beg leave with humble ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, further to offer my late and more private conceptions concerning this thing, and hope hereby I ≈øhall offend none: but rather prove, as a whete≈øtone to a knife, to beget an edge upon ≈øome more Great and Learned then my ≈øelf; to further enlarge this ≈øecret, and bring more light into the World, in re≈øpect to the Original cau≈øe (≈øetting ≈øin a≈øide) of all and every Di≈øea≈øe in Mans body; and more e≈øpecially and perticularly of an Ague concerning which; I have as to its De≈øcription a little more to ≈øay.
Under≈øtand then with me, that every Di≈øea≈øe is admitted to be a being exi≈øting in us, and not from crudities ari≈øing from things taken from without us.

And then I judge an intermitting Feaver or Ague to be; The Archeus, inraged, di≈øturbed, confu≈øed or di≈øthrowned by Ideas, conceived or inplanted in him, by a formative power: the Archeus him≈øelf according to the diver≈øities of his motion, ≈øtirring up ≈øundry and various Symptomes: For to me it appears plainly that every Ague is cau≈øed from the violent a≈ø≈øaulting Spirit, by Ideas conceived in the proper of the Archeus, by who≈øe fault alone, a living body ≈øuffers all di≈øea≈øes; and hence it is that many times ≈øpecifical Medicines excel in the curing the mo≈øt de≈øperate Agues. And hence it is al≈øo that the Ague begins with cold, becau≈øe the Spirits being to enter combat with a ≈øtrong Enemy, gather from every part aid; the outward member in the mean while Quaking; for the truth is, this Spirit is the Prince of the World in us, and hath alone obtained a motive beginning in us; as well Local as Alterative; containing the cau≈øe of rigor or extremity of cold, as well in re≈øpect of Local motion, as the Alteration of cold to ≈øucce≈ø≈øive heat.

The Archeus or Spirit, intending by trembling rigors, As a Learned Man ob≈øerves, to ≈øhake off the excrements adhering to the Similer parts, and to quit it ≈øelf from a forraign gue≈øs. If this may contribute to further the Under≈øtanding of any concerning an Ague, and excite them to a further manife≈øtation this way: I ≈øhall be truly glad, however I have ≈øpake my pre≈øent Apprehentions, and at pre≈øent mu≈øt leave it to your Con≈øiderations, hoping that what may be found wanting to your content in the one, may be made up in the other: for this is all we have to offer at pre≈øent as to the fir≈øt thing, the De≈øcirption of an Ague; and ≈øo ≈øhall pa≈øs to the next which is,

Secondly, The Cure of an Ague. There are ≈øeveral (ways propounded and at this day in practi≈øe to cure Agues, by the learned and Juditions which the common and vulgar people have confu≈øedly jumbled together, and ≈øo advi≈øe the ≈øame Medicines in a Quotidian or every day Ague, as in a Tertian or every other day Ague, or in a Quartane or every third day Ague, having no re≈øpect to the nature, time or complication of the≈øe Di≈øea≈øes. My intentions herein are real and purely for the good of my Neighbours, whom I pitty when I ≈øee them quake and grone under the≈øe Di≈øtempers, and therefore ≈øhall indeavour plainly to make known the cure thereof; ≈øo far as I judge them apprehen≈øive, and I have apprehended.

I begin with a Quotidian Ague, which may be di≈øtingui≈øhed from a Double Tertian or a Triple Quartan, though they both come every day as a Quotidian, by its comming for the mo≈øt part in the night ≈øea≈øon, without ≈øhaking, and hath only a coldne≈øs or light ≈øhivering, and the heat and thir≈øt but ≈ømall.

To cure this kind of Ague you mu≈øt ob≈øerve before the third fit to give or take a Vomit either of Infu≈øion of Crocus Metalorum, or a Do≈øe of Mercurius Vite, which in this ca≈øe is very excellent in ≈øtrong bodies; and be≈øure to give it at that time that is mo≈øt remote≈øt from the Fit: it matters not whether it be morning noon or afternoon; only let the ≈øtomach be empty of all food.
And if the body be ≈øtrong, of evil habit and abounding with obnoctious humours, if need be you may give it a ≈øecond time, otherwi≈øe once will ≈øerve.

If the Ague go not away with this, then again≈øt the next fit following, prepare this decoction following, give it half an hour before the fit cometh and either walk roundly after it, or be covered warm upon the bed. Take Chamomil Flower and Wormwood of each a ≈ømall handful Juniper berries 100. brui≈øed, Cinamon 1 dram, boil all in a pint of White-Wine to half, ≈øtrain it and add 2 ounces of Sugar and drink it three days together if need be, one hour afore the fit cometh; and the Ague I ≈øu≈øpect may leave you.
Secondly, The cure of a Tertian or every other day Ague.

Give a vomit of the Infu≈øion Crocus Metalorum, or Mercurius Vitae, as afore≈øaid on the well day, or 2 hours after the fit, and before the third fit cometh; and the next well day give this purge following. Take Electuary Diacathoricon one ounce, Cremor Tartar. 1 ≈øcruple, mix them and eat upon the point of a knife, drinking warm broath 3 hours after, forbearing to eat till noon.

The next well day be let blood, if you be not to weak: and take away le≈øs or more according as it may offend either in quantity or quality, or is good or bad: If yet the fit remain then prepare, or cau≈øe to be prepared, one of the≈øe Specifical Medicines following, which ≈øeldom mi≈øs in curing, e≈øpecially coming after a general Evacuation of corrupt humours by tho≈øe Medicines afore≈øaid.
Take of the Juice of Plantane 4 ounces, Ro≈øe Vinegar half an ounce Saffron 4 grains in pouder mix all together, and give it almo≈øt an hour before the fit.

Or, Give one Dram of the Pouder of the Herb called Cinquefoil, in a quarter of a pint of Sack, in which is mixed 2 or 3 drops of Spirit of Saffron, ‚Ä¢ Cynamon, take it half an hour before the Fit comes. A≈øtrologers ≈øay, let Jupeter be anguler and ≈øtrong when it is gathered, it being an Herb of that Planet. But I have ≈øeveral times proved the ≈øame with good ≈øucce≈øs: yet have ha ‚Ä¢ no re≈øpect unto the times of gathering the ≈øame, becau≈øe God is ≈øtrong of goodne≈øs and Power, the Trees, Herbs, and Seeds, in the Creation, was before the Sun, Moon, or Stars were Created, Gen. 1.11, 12, 13.
Or, Take Sal Ab≈øinthy, half a dram, Spiritus of Sulphoris Plampanum, one Scruple, Aqua Card. Benedictus. four Ounces.

This I have often tried, and very ≈øeldom hath it failed in an≈øwering my Expectation, either by way of Divertion, if not, of total Curation. Ob≈øerve after the taking of any of the≈øe three la≈øt mentioned Things; you mu≈øt take to your Bed, and be covered warm for four hours. You may renew the taking of them as often as you ≈øee cau≈øe, but u≈øually three times is ≈øufficient, except the Ague be very ≈øtubborn indeed, and al≈øo if the Body be ≈øtrong and can bear it; and full of bad Humour, and require it; you mu≈øt Vomit, and Purge as afore≈øaid two or three times: Only ob≈øerve, that you mu≈øt do it in the fir≈øt place, and let the other Medicines ≈øucceed, and not the Vomit, or Purge; the other Medicines accept ≈øome other particular Indication thereunto: This rule being ob≈øerved, ≈øeldom will you mi≈øs of Cure in a Tartian, or every other dayes Ague, e≈øpecially if you begin time enough.
